name: chemi-thermomechanical pulp production | chemi-thermomechanical pulp | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/2382/documentation

This dataset characterises the average production of pulp following a chemi-thermomechanical process (CTMP) in Europe. ;;In the CTMP wood chips are impregnated with chemicals before they are mechanically defibrated in the refiner under high pressure (~about 3 bar) or at atmospheric pressure, mainly in two stages.;;Bleaching has not been included because chemi-mechanical pulps cannot be brightened effectively by oxidative and reductive bleaching. During mechanical defibration, lignin is plasticised and remains in the pulp.;PULP MARKET: Of the total pulp production in Europe the largest part is sulfate /kraft-pulp, making up about 70% of total pulp production. Thermo-mechanical pulp is a type of mechanical pulp, which makes up around 25-28% of total pulp production, of which in turn the largest part, about 85%, is thermo-mechanical pulp and the rest chemi-thermomechanical pulp. Only a part of pulp production is sold on the market, the majority is produced at integrated pulp mills which directly process it further into (paper-) products. For mechanical pulp the share of market pulp is small, much in 2016 was 9%, the other 92% is integrated pulp.;The SOURCES of information are (1) a report of the Swedish EPA about the Swedish pulp and paper industry (Naturvardsverket, 2001), (2) an environmental report of a Norwegian CTMP mill (Södra, 2002), (3) the European IPPC documentation for the paper and pulp industry, which also contains information on Best Available Techniques (BAT) and the description and quantification of the present situation of the pulp and paper industry (European Commission, 2000), (4) information on the present situation of a Finnish CTMP mill and (5) the theoretical description of Patt et al. (1993).;Reference(s):;Naturvardsverket, 2001. Naturvardsverket (2001) Skogsindustrins utsläpp - avfallsmängder och energiförbrukning 2000. Report 5154. Naturvardsverket (Swedish EPA), Stockholm.;Södra (2002) Meeting Södra. Environmental Report 2001. Södra, Växjö (Sweden) as pdf-File under: www.sodra.com.;European Commission, 2000. European Commission (2000) Integrated Pollution Prevention and Control (IPPC) - Reference Document on Best Available Techniques in the Pulp and Pa-per Industry. Institute for Prospective Technological Studies, Sevilla.;Patt R., Kordsachia O., Süttinger R., Ohtani Y., Hoesch J. F., Ehrler P., Eich-inger R., Holik H., Hamm U., Rohmann M. E., Mummenhoff P., Petermann E., Miller R. F., Frank D., Wilken R., Baumgarten H. L. and Rentrop G.-H. (1993) Paper and Pulp. In: Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Vol. A.18. VCH Publisher Inc.

The activity starts with the reception of residual softwood at the mill.


The process includes raw material handling, pulping, drying, recovery cycles of chemicals and internal wastewater treatment. The activity ends when the chemi-thermomechanical pulp is ready to be sold.
category: C:Manufacturing/17:Manufacture of paper and paper products/170:Manufacture of paper and paper products/1701:Manufacture of pulp, paper and paperboard

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The dataset represents the average chemi-thermomechanical pulp production in Europe. Data are sourced from various European producers, for exaple, in Switzerland and Germany.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data were collected from literature and industry data.
